DOC.HEAD: Marshals Begin Screening Packages in Wake of Attack
Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to reflect death of lawyer in Savannah
With AM-Judge-Explosion Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Marshals Service began screening packages entering U.S. courthouses Monday, mindful of the mailed bomb that killed an appellate judge in Alabama and a suspected bomb found at an Atlanta courthouse. ``We're being more vigilant,'' said Flavio Lorenzoni, Chief Deputy U.S. Marshal for the Southern District of New York. ``All packages are being checked carefully.'' He spoke before it was learned that another mailed bomb had killed a lawyer in Savannah, Ga. Like his colleagues in other judicial districts, Lorenzoni declined to elaborate about the security procedures that have been invoked since the assassination of Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance. ``If we tell everyone what we're doing, it won't have any effect,'' he said. William Dempsey, a spokesman for the Marshals Service in Washington, said judges have been told ``to bring all packages to the attention of the marshals so they can be screened and X-rayed before opening.'' All packages should be screened, even those bearing a familiar return address because ``a return address can be faked or forged,'' he said. Although he said that security for judges is being stepped up around the country, Dempsey acknowledged that it would be impossible for the Marshals Service to provide round-the-clock protection for every federal judge and magistrate. Such protection is given judges when a specific threat is detected, usually arising from a case involving a judge. ``There is not a day in a year that goes by that we do not have round-the-clock details on some judges,'' Dempsey said. Dempsey confirmed that extra security had given to judges in the 11th Circuit, which covers Florida, Georgia, and Alabama, following Saturday's blast that killed Vance at his home outside Birmingham. In Miami, Daniel J. Horgan, U.S. Marshal for the Southern District of Florida, called a meeting Monday of the district's judges to inform them of the apparent bomb found in Atlanta on Monday and the new security measures. Chief Deputy U.S. Marshal James Tassone said all packages and mail entering the federal courthouses in Miami, West Palm Beach and Fort Lauderdale were being inspected by X-ray. People entering the courthouses also were subjected to extra examination. For instance, some courthouse employees who usually pass through security with a cursory check were asked Monday to empty their pockets as they entered. Not all federal courthouses changed procedures. For instance, in Indiana, officials said security was already tight and did not need to be improved. However, Deputy Marshal Jeff Whitney in Evansville, Ind., said judges had been instructed not to open any uninspected packages In New York, U.S. District Judge Mark A. Costantino said federal marshals called him at home several hours after Judge Vance was killed and advised him to be alert for suspicious packages. The judge said he and his family would refuse to accept any parcel not bearing the return address of someone they know. ``We may be making a mountain out of a molehill, but that shows that someone is making an effort to create fear in the judicial system,'' he said. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush had been in contact with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to ask about the status of the investigation. ``The attorney general advised him we have not reached any conclusions about the source of his death. We just don't have any answers yet as to who might have done it to him,'' Fitzwater said. Extra security precautions have been taken at the Justice Department in recent months since President Virgilio Barcos of Colombia declared war that nation's cocaine cartels. The Justice Department purchased an armor-plated limousine for Thornburgh, which the attorney general uses around Washington. The FBI agents who guard Thornburgh now carry high-powered assault weapons in leather cases.
